titleInfo.title: Relative susceptiptibility of Najdi, Neimi and Hari lambs indigenous to Saudi Arabia to experimental infection with Haemonchus contortus

name.affiliation: Department of Biology, College of Science, King Faisal University, P O Box 55017, Al-Ahsa 31982, Saudi Arabia.
Department of Microbiology and Parasitology, College of Veterinary Medicine and Animal Resources, King Faisal University, P O Box 1757, Al-Ahsa 31982, Saudi Arabia.
Department of Microbiology and Parasitology, College of Veterinary Medicine and Animal Resources, King Faisal University, P O Box 1757, Al-Ahsa 31982, Saudi Arabia.
Department of Medical Microbiology, College of Medicine, King Faisal University, P O Box 55017, Al-Ahsa 31982, Saudi Arabia.

mods.abstract: Ten lambs of each of Najdi, Neimi and Hari breeds were inoculated with 400, 1600 or 16000 Haemonchus contortus third stage larvae (L3). The lambs developed subclinical forms of Haemonchus infection as they remained alert. The lambs maintained a steady growth rate, PCV values within the normal range, egg voidance tended to increase in all lambs proportional to dose of infective larvae and showed no significant (P>0.5) differences between the three breeds.

titleInfo.title: Journal of Food, Agriculture and Environment
